byline.contributor: James Kanter contributed reporting from Brussels, and David M. Herszenhorn from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: The European Union confirmed the existence of a list of officials that Russia has barred, a move thought to be retaliation for the group’s barring of Russians said to have backed the annexation of Crimea.

headline.print_headline: Russia’s Barring of Officials Seen as Reprisal for Sanctions
headline.main: Russia’s Barring of Officials Seen as Reprisal

snippet: The European Union confirmed the existence of a list of officials that Russia has barred, a move thought to be retaliation for the group’s barring of Russians said to have backed the annexation of Crimea.
abstract: Russia bars dozens of European officials from entering its territory; move appears to be retaliation for European Union's ban of Russian officials and businessmen that were said to have supported annexation of Crimea and takeover by Russian separatists there.
